title: Wednesday, 3rd May, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am

BE11:10am

BE11:10am

BE11:10am

Via the Kleinmanator, among others.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

The only surprise here is that his successor hasn't been named at the same time.

BE11:11am

Why? Dunno.

PM11:11am

Does that suggest they have struggled to find one?

11:11 am
PM11:11am

How long have the search firm been on the case?

BE11:12am

Five months, is it?

BE11:12am

And we're still "in due course" for the new person.

11:12 am
PM11:12am

Suppose you have to string it out to justify the fees

PM11:13am

Here's the statement btw: http://www.investe...1705030700120062E/

BE11:13am

Anyway, how to read this? The best summary I've chanced on this morning is Jefferies.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Liberty owns 9.9% of ITV and is frequently discussed in the press as a potential acquirer of ITV. The change in CEO may lead some to view this as more or less likely.

BE11:13am

Yep. True. It's either more or less likely.

PM11:13am

hehehe

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Let's start with the "more" take.

BE11:14am

Liberum, of course. Whose "buy" advice on ITV is like the ravens at the Tower.

BE11:14am

Potentially the most interesting part of the announcement is that Ian Griffiths is to step up to take the combined role of COO / FD (from FD) while Sir Peter Balzagette will become Executive Chairman. This has echoes of a decade ago when Ian Griffiths was in his previous job at Emap as FD and Emap’s then CEO stepped down. Ian Griffiths and the Chairman (Alun Cathcart) ran the company together without a CEO and were responsible for breaking up Emap and selling off its assets at a high price (and just before the 2008 financial crisis).

11:14 am
BE11:14am

This is not to say History will repeat itself but it would provide one explanation as to why ITV has not announced a new CEO when there have been signs that the company has prepared for the departure of Adam Crozier for several months i.e. that there is a reasonable chance of a bid coming through for ITV. It would certainly make more sense than one suggestion we have heard that ITV has not been able to “find” a CEO “because no one will take the job” (as History shows, CEO roles, no matter how unappealing structurally, are not left unfilled when the rewards are right).

BE11:14am

On a potential bid, Liberty Media (NR), which owns 9.9%, will be inevitably mentioned but maybe one option to consider is a joint bid by Liberty and Discovery (NR), with whom Liberty has close links. The two companies acquired jointly All3 Media (one of the UK’s then leading independent production houses) in 2014 and both Liberty and Discovery have been acquiring European free to air broadcasters.

PM11:15am

That last par is an interesting line

11:15 am
PM11:15am

Didnt know about the All3 Media purchase

PM11:15am

http://www.all3media.com/

BE11:16am

Crozier, for all our reactive snideness when presented with any news whatsoever, has done well at ITV.

11:16 am
BE11:17am

The studio stuff has weakened, if not removed, the link between monthly "media buyer feedback" and its share price.

BE11:17am

The balance sheet was fixed without too much pain to the equity holders.

PM11:17am

Actually, the stock dipped below 30p during the worst of the Crunch back in 2009

11:17 am
BE11:18am

Yup. One can argue that ITV's still a terrestrial broadcaster in a world that doesn't need those any more. But that's not really his fault is it? He's leaving ITV in better shape than when he arrived.

PM11:18am

Substantially so

BE11:18am

Whether that's good shape is another question entirely, though, and for that I turn to Neil Campling of Northern Trust.

11:18 am
PM11:18am

This is the "less likely" take

BE11:19am

It is. Neil's argument is, "yes, but it's ITV."

BE11:19am

Which seems fair, I guess.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

It is somewhat surprising that ITV haven't been able to find a successor yet for Crozier In our view. They've had 5/6 months as ITV begun laying the groundwork for the departure by hiring headhunters Spencer Stuart to oversee succession plan in December (Source: Sky News). Crozier has been at the helm of ITV since 2010 and has, to be fair, done a stellar job in improving the fortunes of the company and diversifying into content. But Mr Crozier leaves at a time the Global media landscape is changing dramatically like
never before. Consumption habits are changing at pace and the shift towards streaming media and even towards non traditional media such as video game streams leaves ITV vulnerable. For example, the latest SuperData shows there is now a larger game video streaming audience than there is an audience of Netflix, HBO, Hulu and ESPN combined.

BE11:19am

Crozier deciding to leave should also pour some cold water on the incessant takeover expectations which have seemed to appear in the U.K. Press on an almost daily occurrence. And one on which we remain sceptical on. Simply we can't see significant interest in the highly cyclical U.K. Broadcasting business and most of the content assets are in unscripted media which has low barriers to entry/creation relative to scripted drama. In fact, Netflix for example is targeting organic scale in unscripted in 2017 and the same could pressure ITV's own offering.

We remain sellers of ITV for structural reasons related to the changes in media consumption and relative positioning versus global peers.

PM11:20am

hmm

11:20 am
PM11:20am

The more/less likely split is mirrored in the price today -- which has barely moved

PM11:20am

But let's move on

undefined
11:20 am
PM11:20am

Quite a few trading statements out today

PM11:21am

Footsie off, but not dramatically so

BE11:21am

In terms of the updates there's Sainsbury.

11:21 am
J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY:LSE): Last: 266.70, down 12.8 (-4.58%), High: 277.00, Low: 266.20, Volume: 10.88m
BE11:22am

Numbers pretty poor at the Sainsbury bit of the business.

BE11:22am

Less bad at the Argos bit of the business.

11:22 am
PM11:22am

Finals here: http://www.investe...1705030700109748D/

BE11:23am

Headline numbers are in line, but 2018 guidance seems to undershoot consensus.

BE11:23am

Here comes Morgan Stanley for a summary.

11:23 am
BE11:24am

Bottom line: Overall, the bulls will find comfort in the fact that Argos' profitability came in a touch above expectations in FY17 as the business was smoothly integrated, and that Argos' contribution to Group profit in FY18 should be slightly higher than current market expectations (by £5-10m), as good unit economics are leading Sainsbury to accelerate the roll out of Argos digital stores in its supermarkets. However, this positive development will largely be offset, we believe, by ongoing pressure on the profitability of Sainsbury's grocery business (we expect the division's EBIT to fall another 6% in FY18 to ~£518m) which continues to face a number of industry headwinds. All in all, we do not expect FY18 underlying PBT (currently at £573m) to move much on the back of today's results (we lower our FY18 PBT estimate from £595m to £579m). Given that the shares were strong going into the numbers as the market was expecting a small beat, and given the fact that profit generation in FY18 will be back end loaded, we would expect the share to be slightly down today.

PM11:24am

I notice they've also trimmed the divi

BE11:24am

In the sense of the new policy? Yes.

11:24 am
BE11:25am

Divi cover will now be 2 times.

PM11:25am

affordable dividend policy

BE11:25am

Which means a final of 6.6p, down 18.5% YOY.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

But that was already flagged to the sellside I think, and was in the consensus.

BE11:25am

Shore says .........

BE11:25am

Against its peers, this DPS represents an attractive full year yield of c3.7% to our minds, and fuelled by the combination of the supermarket business, Argos and the combined synergies, we expect the income stream to now build on an ongoing basis. Indeed, with a strengthened balance sheet, partially reflecting the capital injection to finance the Argos acquisition, we were pleased to see FY2017 net debt (‘ND’) fall by £349m to £1.48bn.

11:25 am
PM11:26am

Seems rather disciplined

BE11:26am

Sticking with Shore for the guidance side ...........

BE11:26am

Looking into FY2018, we note that Sainsbury speaks of profitability in H1 being below H2, which is something that we had been expecting from the company. With this guidance in-tow, we expect to be cutting our Sainsbury Supermarkets Limited (SSL) forecasts, noting the lower base than we previously anticipated from FY2017, where margins eased a little.

Management guides to 2.0-3.0% cost inflation in FY2018 offset by c£145m of cost savings with the consolidation of the H1 Argos losses, the annualisation of FY2017 price investment and wage awards in SSL impacting the anticipated H1 out-turn; overall Sainsbury states that it is on-track to deliver c£500m of cost savings to FY2018, with a further £500m of savings expected from FY2019-21. We are very encouraged that Argos synergy expectations in aggregate are reiterated by management and we are particularly pleased that an experienced team has played the long-ball game in guidance and so generated a position to bring forward the overall £160m EBITDA target by six months. Sainsbury Bank is guided by the company to deliver c10% trading profit growth in FY2018, in-line with our expectations.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Overall, therefore, our expectations for FY2018 operating performances from Sainsbury’s feel a little too high, the miss being from SSL with both Argos and the Bank broadly unchanged. Where we are a little further out in our model is with financing costs, where management is guiding to FY2018 year-end ND of c£1.5bn (SC forecast; £1.3bn) and so aggregate financing costs of c£120m versus our £90m forecast. Combined, therefore, we expect following the analyst meeting and finessing of the models, to be bringing our top end FY2018 PTP expectations for Sainsbury down by c7-10%. Now, we clearly would rather not be doing so but the exercise allows a fresh examination of the Sainsbury investment case. In this respect, we continue to retain a positive stance for the following reasons:

BE11:27am

· Sainsbury is still expected to deliver onward EPS & DPS growth here on driven by a combination of a relatively stable SSL, admittedly we would rather be recording slightly rising rather than easing EBIT margins in this division, with the c£160m of Argos synergies coming through, indeed with the timing of delivery now reduced by six months.

· Onward growth at Sainsbury Bank.

· A materially strengthened balance sheet noting that relative capital discipline persists with an ongoing rate of annual expenditure, including Argos, of c£675-700m.

BE11:27am

Quite important to our investment thesis on Sainsbury is that the stock trades on normalised earnings multiples, assuming a 10% FY2018 EPS downgrade would yield c21p EPS, so 13x PER with a corresponding undemanding EV/EBITDA ratio of under 6x. As outlined above, Sainsbury also delivers a quite attractive income stream; c21p of EPS on 2.0x cover would make for a FY2018 pay-out of 10.5p, which is a 3.8% yield.

More to the point, to our minds, that yield appears much more secure with the Argos trading profits and synergies in-tow, making for reasonable downside support to the group share. That increased visibility is predicated upon our view that the combined group has the scope to materially de-leverage over the period out to FY2020, so bolstering the security of the forecast income stream.

So, following this solid set of results for FY2017, our recent reservations about the prevailing momentum for SSL reflecting the market share data, have come to pass, making for probable reductions to our high end consensus forecasts for the supermarkets division set against a very pleasing outcome from Argos at first base. Following this update, therefore, we reiterate our BUY stance on Sainsbury shares for the valuations reasons set out above. We shall issue updated forecasts on Sainsbury’s in due course.

Wix.com Touches Record Amid FT Alphaville Speculation on Cisco

(Bloomberg) -- Wix.com rose as much as 4.7% to a record high, before erasing gains, amid earlier FT Alphaville blog which discussed speculation about potential interest in Wix from Cisco.
Today’s move followed a 12% gain on April 25
Wix declined to comment to Bloomberg News; CSCO also declined to comment, citing policy of not comment on rumors or speculation
NOTE: April 19, Wix.com Mentioned Cautiously by Spruce Point

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Here's Singer.

BE11:41am

Halfords' perspective

Jill McDonald will continue in her role at Halfords until end October, during which time Halfords will seek to hire/appoint a successor.
This is disappointing for Halfords, who also lost previous CEO, Matt Davies, to a “bigger” role at Tesco.
Halfords’ Head Office location at Redditch may act as a deterrent to some potential candidates.
While Halfords says results for FY17, to be announced on 25 May, “are expected to be in line with market expectations” (consensus PBT of £74.2m, CGe: £75.0m), share price reaction will likely be negative in our view for Halfords.
Halfords is currently trading on a cal 17 PER of 12.2x, a c 8% discount to the wider sector.

BE11:41am

Marks & Spencer's perspective

From an M&S perspective, Jill McDonald's arrival sees a number of internal management responsibility changes.
Primarily, she will take over responsibility for Clothing, Home & Beauty from Group CEO, Steve Rowe, who had retained responsibility for this division, which was his role prior to his promotion to Group CEO.
Ms McDonald will also take on the supply chain and logistics responsibilities from CFO, Helen Weir.
Jo Jenkins, currently working as Womenswear, Lingerie and Beauty Director, assumes a new role under the title, Clothing & Beauty Director, with “expanded accountabilities for all clothing”, now including menswear and kidswear.
This is an interesting appointment from an M&S perspective, since Ms McDonald, whose prior roles include long stints at McDonalds and BA, cannot be seen as a clothing expert. What she does bring is considerable experience in marketing and Customer Relationship Management (CRM), which have become even greater areas of focus under Steve Rowe’s tenure.
M&S is trading on a cal 17 PER of 12.9x, a c. 2% discount to the wider sector.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Sorry! That was Canaccord, not Singer!

BE11:41am

This is Singer.

BE11:42am

Halfords has announced that the CEO is leaving to take up a senior role at M&S. In our opinion she has added significant additional value to the transformation commenced by Matt Davies, and so we regard her departure as disappointing. Jill will stay on for her 6 months notice period, so at the very least that ensures a smooth transition and may even allow a successor to be appointed in that timeframe. Critically, the business is in good shape and the market may be under-estimated the potential for full FX mitigation, as outlined in our recent note dated 23 March (Confidence in FX mitigation grows, stay at Buy”). However, the last time the CEO departed prematurely the shares fell more than 10%. We suspect the same thing might happen this time too. In light of the increased uncertainty around the leadership we have reduced our target price by 5% to 400p. Having performed well recently, we would regard any big sell off as a new buying opportunity ahead of prelims at the end of the month.

11:41 am
BE11:42am

That was Singer, not Canaccord. Hope that's clear.

PM11:42am

PM11:42am

BE11:42am

Mitie mentioned.

11:42 am
Mitie Group PLC (MTO:LSE): Last: 224.52, up 13.12 (+6.21%), High: 230.70, Low: 205.00, Volume: 6.99m
BE11:43am

Writedowns ignored, core trading vaguely reassuring.

BE11:43am

And a massive short, because it's in the massive-short sector.

11:43 am
BE11:44am

Here, via Markit, is the short position.

BE11:44am

BE11:45am

So, nearly 18% of free float and not much in the way of borrow out there.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

In that context, you're expecting volatility.

BE11:45am

Here's UBS to summarise where he good news is.

BE11:46am

Mitie has released an update on its accounting review: we overall see the writedowns as slightly larger than expected (including a £10-20m prior year restatement), but there is no change to the underlying performance of the business and this is an important step for renewal. Cashflow is better than expected and Mitie is within covenants, although they will be renegotiated to allow for more headroom ahead of further potential changes. A rapid (if necessary) renewal is well underway.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

In addition to the £14m writedown announced Jan-17, the review will lead to further writedowns of £40-50m. This is broadly composed of £20-25m accrued income (vs. Total balance £236m at FY16), £10-12.5m intangible assets, and £10-12.5m receivables; there is only a £6m cash component (legacy claims). In addition, Mitie will restate FY16 profits down by £10-20m due to 'material errors', with an opposing benefit for FY17e (e.g. Costs wrongly not recognised within FY16). We would therefore see FY16 EBITA of £108.9-118.9m (margin 4.8%-5.3%), FY17e EBITA of £42-62m including writedowns and excluding Healthcare (margin 1.9%-2.9%), and at this point no change to UBSe £94.1m for FY18e (margin 4.4%)

BE11:46am

Mitie's end-FY17e Net Debt of £146m is well below the greater than £200m we had expected. With the receivables financing flat y/y, this represents strong early delivery on cashflow improvements. While this puts Net Debt/EBITDA at 1.7-2.3x, well within convent of 3.0x, there is less headroom on the other covenant for interest cover greater than 4.0x. Mitie is therefore renegotiating to permit more one-off charges in its covenant test ahead of more potential changes as it takes a more cautious approach on its accounts (IFRS15, POC assets, mobilisation costs).

BE11:46am

The results presentation and strategy update have been pushed back to 12th June (rather than May). As well as rebuilding confidence, new management also need to improve the underlying business: underlying revenue was flat in FY17e as expected with gross margins under pressure; from here Mitie needs cost savings (restructuring costs up £5m to £15m now) and reinvestment (e.g. to build a 'connected workspace' offering).

11:47 am
BE11:47am

So, if you were short for a rights issue you might see enough here to close. That's probably worth 6% on the price, I guess.

BE11:47am

RBC as well, since we're here.

BE11:47am

Whilst clearly MITIE was in a mess, the key with this statement is that trading is in line, the FY net debt position is better than expected and the balance sheet review has been completed without any significant negative cashflow or ongoing impacts. Hence we would not expect any changes to 2018 forecasts today. Stock trades on a calendarised 18E PE 11.3x, FCF Yield 6.6% and Div Yield 4.3%. We remain at Sector Perform, there are clear risks and trading remains tough, but we expect the new management team to make some significant improvements to the business over the next 18m.

11:52 am

PM11:52am

Our Growth Brands are Davidoff, Gauloises Blondes, JPS, West, Fine, News, Winston, Bastos, Lambert & Butler and Parker & Simpson. These are quality brands with broad consumer appeal that are generating an increasing amount of our volume and revenue.

PM11:52am

Specialist Brands appeal to specific consumer groups and include: blu (e-vapour), Style, Gitanes, Kool (cigarettes), Golden Virginia, Drum, Route 66 (fine cut tobacco), Cohiba, Montecristo, Romeo Y Julieta (premium cigars), Backwoods (cigars), Skruf (snus) and Rizla (papers). Our specialist brand Style is being migrated to Jadé as part of our new Chinese joint venture. Jadé will eventually replace Style as one of our Specialist Brands as we build scale behind Jadé for further development outside of China.

11:53 am

BE11:55am

11:55 am
BE11:55am

RBC incoming to summarise.

BE11:55am

Imperial Brands reported 1H17 adjusted EPS of 121.9 pence, 1% ahead of consensus at 120.4 pence, on the back of total adjusted operating profit of £1,740m and net revenue of £4,158, both in line with consensus. Organic revenue growth for H1 came in at -5.5%, on the back of underlying volumes down 5.7%. As previously indicated by the company, pricing in H1 was impacted by increased investments, phasing of price increases and the impact of the termination of PMI contracts in the UK and Morocco.

The company flagged that increased investments are strengthening share trends in many priority markets, although we note that with Portfolio brands share down 90bps vs growth brands up 60bps, share loss for the group is continuing.

Finally, the company said it now expects to deliver £130m of savings in FY17 vs £90m announced at its full-year results in November and confirmed it is on track to meet full-year earnings expectations.

BE11:58am

Exane summarises it as "a rather dull release", which is why I guess we've been talking about caffeine lozenges and Backwood cigars instead.
